section.title: IPFS Content Addressing
section.p: Content itself can be used to derive a unique identifier called a hash. The Interplanetary File System, or IPSF, uses the content's SHA-256 to locate the image.

fig.title: July is Disability Pride Month
fig.desc: Photograph of Disability Pride flag viewed through an orange heart stencil.
fig.p: The following descriptive text was copied from the Ashland Public Library.

q.p: Ashland Public Library, Ashland, Oregon, USA
Green is for sensory disabilities, including deafness and blindness.
Blue represents emotional and psychiatric disabilities, including mental illness, anxiety and depression.
White stands for non-visible and undiagnosed disabilities.

The stripes are displayed on a faded charcoal black background which commemorates and mourns disabled people who've died due to ableism, violence, ableism, violence, negligence, suicide, rebellion, illness and eugenics.

fig.title: Human Rights - Dweb Camp 2022 Notes
fig.desc: Digital rendering of paint/ink of handwritten notes and paint about a human-rights centered design agency assisting with online safety.
fig.p: Orange heart outline around handwritten notes about a human rights centered design agency based in NYC/Berline with additional notes on dweb values such as diversity and inclusion. Chat GPT 4o was used to flatten the image backgrond.

image.alt: Orange heart with the words "HUMAN RIGHTS CENTERED DESIGN BASED IN NYC/BERLIN" surrounded by additional notes that say "Public Research Technologies", "looks at threat models. Staff is secure and careful. Goals: provide resources, usable security, open source", "Change who technology serves". An overlay of other notes documents DWeb values of diversity, inclusion, model tech around common good".

fig.title: Elephant Rock
fig.desc: Photograph of Elephant Rock, a naturally formed geological landmark on the road to Dillon Beach, viewed through an orange heart stencil. Rock indentations form the elephant's eyes, and the top of its trunk and limbs. The rock formation is viewed through a blurry orange stencil.
fig.p: Marin County landmark frequently used while providing directions to Dillon Beach. Several hundred yards away, a sign warns drivers that the GPS directions to the beach are incorrect.
Elephant Rock, Dillon Beach, Marin County, California, USA

image.alt: Natural gray rock formation which resembles an elephant looking down framed by an orange heart stencil. Rock indentations on what looks like the torso resemble the top of the elephant's limbs.
